data.title: 14 Best R&B Love Songs of All Time
data.meta_description: Check out our list of the best R&B love songs, including slow jams, romantic tunes and music to make your heart flutter.
data.text:
No genre knows love better than R&B. The Motown songbook alone contains enough lessons of the heart to fill several medical textbooks. Sure, many great soul songs are about the dark side of love â€“ jealousy, betrayal, breakups, etc. But thatâ€™s not why you came to this list, is it?

Itâ€™s to find those songs that speak directly to the joy of being with someone else. Whether itâ€™s innocent infatuation, all-consuming obsession or lustful intoxication, thereâ€™s an awesome jam out there to communicate exactly what youâ€™re feeling. And not all of them are of the smooth, old-school variety either. Here, weâ€™ve compiled the absolute best R&B love songs, and while youâ€™ll find plenty of â€˜60s classics, there are several modern, chart-busting pop bangers as well. So letâ€™s get it on, shall we?

RECOMMENDED:ğŸ© The best love songs of all timeğŸ˜­ The best heartbreak songs

ğŸ† The sexiest songs of all time

ğŸ•º The best party songs of all time

1. â€˜Letâ€™s Stay Togetherâ€™ by Al Green

Al Greenâ€™s greatest gift to the world is that he makes love funky. The lyrics to the Reverendâ€™s landmark 1971 hit, â€˜Letâ€™s Stay Together,â€™ articulate the solemn vows of marriage: â€˜Whether times are good or bad, happy or sad.â€™ But sung by Green, these promises are given wings. Covered multiple times since its release, Greenâ€™s gorgeous original was given a new lease on life in â€™94, when Quentin Tarantino featured it in Pulp Fiction. But our favorite boost for this R&B love song has to be the snippet sung by President Obama at a fundraising event in 2012, naughty smile and all.

2. â€˜My Girlâ€™ by the Temptations

This sugary â€™64 chart-topper (the Temptationsâ€™ first) might be the best puppy-love song of all time. Penned by fellow Motown signees the Miracles, its instantly recognizable guitar riff (right up there with the one from â€˜Satisfactionâ€™), peppy finger snaps, unabashed optimism and comforting-as-a-much-needed-hug harmonies can make even the most jaded downer feel all warm inside.

Advertising

3. â€˜Dilemmaâ€™ by Nelly ft. Kelly Rowland

Probably one of the best duets ever. If youâ€™re looking to woo a partner via the medium of the karaoke mic, this is a sure way to achieve that (probably). How can so few words convey so much emotion? You tell us, Nelly. Though perhaps not the best example of a song extolling the virtues of a monogamous relationship (the refrain â€˜Even when Iâ€™m with my boo / All I think about is youâ€™ raises a few questions) who are we to judge? A bangerâ€™s a banger.

Marina Rabin

Contributing writer

4. â€˜Untitled (How Does It Feel?)â€™ by Dâ€™Angelo

Coupled with soul man Dâ€™Angeloâ€™s extraordinary songwriting chops and an exquisitely chiseled body, the video for â€˜Untitledâ€™ is almost too much to watch; the singer is naked as far as the eye can see, and he licks his lips as he sings the songâ€™s refrain (he was thinking of his grandmaâ€™s home cooking, he maintains). Video aside, thereâ€™s also that delicious, almost unbearable musical climax. Press play, and youâ€™ll see what we mean.

Advertising

5. â€˜Love on Topâ€™ by BeyoncÃ©

BeyoncÃ© is queen of the love songs (albeit the tunes on that affair in recent years). Love on Top was released in 2011 when we were all still bright eyed, bushy tailed and full of belief in her and Jay-Zâ€™s R&B royalty love story. When things were a bit more â€˜honey honeyâ€™ and a bit less Becky with the good hair. Love on Top is brimming with this kind of optimism, as BeyoncÃ© unapologetically belts about the joys of true love. Itâ€™s also creatively ambitious - BeyoncÃ© challenged herself by moving up four keys at the end of the song to achieve those raw, elated vocals.

Marina Rabin

Contributing writer

6. â€˜Wonderful Worldâ€™ by Sam Cooke

If thereâ€™s anyone out there whose heart doesnâ€™t melt just a little bit when they hear the drum flutter that opens this 1960 swoon of an R&B love song, weâ€™ll eat our hat. â€˜Wonderful Worldâ€™ is lullaby-simple in its structureâ€”of course one and one is two! Of course this one should be with you!â€”echoing the way that when love feels right, itâ€™s somewhere between a no-brainer and a miracle. And no, we still donâ€™t know what a slide rule is for.

Advertising

7. â€˜Thinkin Bout Youâ€™ by Frank Ocean

There's little direct allusion to sex in this minimal Frank Ocean masterwork, perhaps the highlight of 2012's widely swooned-over Channel Orange. But that lighters-in-the-air falsetto in the chorus and the brief stunner of a bridgeâ€”â€˜You know you were my first time / A new feelâ€™â€”make this a boudoir ballad for the ages. What's a bigger turn-on, after all, than knowing you've been on your lover's mind?

8. â€˜Do Right Woman, Do Right Manâ€™ by Aretha Franklin

Has the Queen of Soul ever sounded more desirable than when she opens this ballad with the eternal couplet, â€˜Take me to heart / And I'll always love you.â€™ Over the kind of slow-burn groove that has inspired bedroom moves for decades, Aretha sings of intense desireâ€¦but don't you dare forget to respect her while you work your moves.

Steve Smith

Advertising

9. â€˜If I ainâ€™t got youâ€™ by Alicia Keys

Another belter beloved by â€˜X Factorâ€™ contestants throughout the ages, this is a song about reminding yourself whatâ€™s important in life. Apparently partly inspired by the 2001 death of the princess of R&B Aaliyah, the song is a reminder to live in the present, and hold the one we love close as everything is transient. Alicia doesnâ€™t care about the materialistic trappings of diamond rings and roses which other people want â€“ when these things are gone all weâ€™re left with is the love weâ€™ve had. Is someone chopping onions?

Marina Rabin

Contributing writer

10. â€˜When a Man Loves a Womanâ€™ by Percy Sledge

Percy Sledgeâ€™s R&B (and wedding-soundtrack) staple might be one of the most romantic-sounding songs of all time, but the 1966 hitâ€™s lyrics basically boil down to this: Love fucks everything upâ€”your judgment, your pride, your friendships, your bank account, the roof over your head. It can be a powerful, fickle bitch, in other words. Oh, also: When youâ€™re under its spell, itâ€™s the absolute greatest thing in the world.

Advertising

11. â€˜Signed, Sealed, Delivered Iâ€™m Yoursâ€™ by Stevie Wonder

Stevie Wonder was a mere 20 years old when he released his apologetic anthem â€˜Signed, Sealed, Delivered Iâ€™m Yours.â€™ Even at that tender age, the Detroit prodigy had â€˜done a lot of foolish thingsâ€™ that he â€˜really didnâ€™t mean,â€™ but making that record wasnâ€™t one of them. It spent six weeks atop the U.S. R&B chart and garnered Wonder his first Grammy nomination, proving that everyone loves a second chance.

12. â€˜Ainâ€™t Nobodyâ€™ by Rufus & Chaka Khan

This dance masterpiece from the â€˜80s never gets old. This song perfectly encapsulates the bliss of being so enamoured by that one person that everyone else might as well be invisible. The genius of Rufus and Chaka Khan managed to create a song which feels like being wrapped in a warm embrace to listen to, yet will also get people dancing every. Single. Time. And itâ€™s next to impossible to resist screaming along to that chorus. Thereâ€™s a reason this has remained a dancefloor staple for so many decades.

Marina Rabin

Contributing writer

Advertising

13. â€˜Ainâ€™t No Mountain High Enoughâ€™ by Marvin Gaye & Tammi Terrell

From the twinkling intro to the rocket-powered chorus, this classic 1967 duet, featuring two of Motownâ€™s most stirring voices, makes a convincing argument for the superheroic qualities of love - the feeling that you can scale any mountain, swim any river, cross any valley, if you know that one special person is on the other side.

Matthew Singer

Film writer and editor

14. â€˜Adornâ€™ by Miguel

With an opening salvo like â€˜these lips can't wait to taste your skin,â€™ things get steamy quick on Miguel's 2012 sex-soaked R&B love song. Armed with a deadly falsetto, the crooner melds the sweetness of a young Marvin Gaye with the swag of in-the-club-like-yeah Usherâ€”it's damn near irresistible.

Advertising

15. â€˜Climaxâ€™ by Usher

One thing you can count on with Usher is consistency: Two decades into his career, the slick singer is still releasing songs as titillating as, say, â€˜Bad Girl.â€™ â€˜Climaxâ€™ dropped on Valentineâ€™s Day 2012, and it's as surefire a soundtrack for horizontal listening as his previous hits; according to Diplo, Usher proposed the idea of â€˜tak[ing] the strip club to the stadiumâ€™ with its production. And with that dead-sexy falsetto and wax-melting grooves, you can hear it.
